dataset.title: Long Term Aquatic Monitoring Program (LTAM) Summer Water Temperature Monitoring in Streams, 2006-2017, in support of the Cedar River Watershed Habitat Conservation Plan for City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities, in King County, Washington

abstract.para: Summer water temperature in streams in deg (F) was collected for the Long Term Aquatic Monitoring (LTAM) program, in support of the Cedar River Watershed Habitat Conservation Plan for City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities, in King County, Washington. Raw and summarized data for all (25) LTAM monitoring sites for 2006-2017 is included in the package.

The focus was to capture the summer high water temperature. Thermistors were placed within or very near the stream monitoring site at the start of the field season in June and removed at the end of the field season in September. A common regulatory metric was calculated from the raw data, the 7 Day Average Daily Maximum Water Temperature. Datasets were quality control checked for out of water, where sites which showed >= 3 degrees (F) difference between Successive Hours or Successive Daily Means were flagged as likely out of water. Of the 110 possible total datasets for 2006-2017, about half were deemed acceptable to move forward for statistical analysis.
For more detailed information on the LTAM program and the statistical analysis, refer to the LTAM Reports and Methods data package

intellectualRights.para: This information is released under the Creative Commons license - Attribution - CC BY (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). The consumer of these data ("Data User" herein) is required to cite it appropriately in any publication that results from its use. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study. While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

contact.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

description.para: The focus was to capture the summer high water temperature. Thermistors were placed within or very near the stream monitoring site at the start of the field season in June and removed at the end of the field season in September. Onset Hobo thermistors were attached to a chain which was then attached to vegetation on the river bank. Thermistors were checked once or twice during the summer, where many of the thermistors went out of water or were only in surficial water.

At the end of the field season, water temperature data was quality control checked to flag likely out of water records. Records that showed >= 3 degrees (F) difference between Successive Hours or Successive Daily Means were removed later during statistical analysis. Of the 110 possible total datasets for 2006-2017, about half were moved forward for statistical analysis.

personnel.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

abstract.para: Long Term Aquatic Monitoring (LTAM) pebble count summary data and individual working data, 2006-2017, in support of the Cedar River Watershed Habitat Conservation Plan, for Seattle Public Utilities in North Bend, Washington. Field methods were based on Wolman Pebble Count methods, e.g. using the blind touch method off the tip of the boot and measuring intermediate b-axis for at least 100 particles, bankfull to bankfull, for all channels at a particular cross section. Data is summarized for each cross section for each year at each site, as well as all cross sections for each year at each site, into particle size class distribution classes and noting p-value significance.

dataTable.entityDescription: A data table of summer water temperature in streams in deg (F) for all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2017. Includes hourly readings as well as daily and weekly averages, minimums, and maximums as recorded in the 23rd hour of each calendar day's record. Out of water data can be inferred from attributes in the table when >= 3 degrees (F) difference occurs in Successive Hours or Successive Daily Means.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Main Sorting No, a number that is used to order records for the purposes of loading data, grouping data, or building formulas.
Method, an abbreviation or acronym whereas the method is a group of methods for a project or program and is described in a separate document.

Year Site ID, a number that is used to group data and is a conjugate of the 4 digit Sample Year and Site No. For example, 20062 refers to Sample Year 2006, Site 2, and 201022 refers to Sample Year 2010, Site 22. If the analysis is a Enter "999" for
Site No, a number that has been assigned to the site, whereas the same site number is used for repeat surveys.
Stream Name (short), the abbreviated or shortened stream name of the site that is being surveyed.

Hobo Number, The hobo or thermistor number as it is printed on the device. If the number has rubbed off, the number should be visible via the software. It is typically a long significant figures number.
Hobo Deployed Timestamp, The Timestamp of when the hobo or thermistor is placed in the water.
Hobo Retrieved Timestamp, The Timestamp of when the hobo or thermistor is removed from the water.
Begin Analysis Timestamp, The day in which analysis should begin, which is usually, at minimum, the day after the device was deployed.
End Analysis Timestamp, The day in which analysis should end, which is usually, at maximum, the day before the device was retrieved.
Hoboware Plot No, The record number as generated by water temperature software after data download.
Timestamp, Timestamp, Date or Date and Time for when the data was collected and in format MM/DD/YYY hh:mm:ss.
Water Temperature deg (F), as recorded by a datalogger or manually recorded from reading a thermometer (refer to survey method).

Water Temperature Difference deg (F) b/w Successive Hours, The absolute (ABS) difference in deg (F) between the current hour water temperature reading and the previous hour water temperature reading, where current refers to any given hour and previous refers to the hour immediately preceding the current hour. If hourly data exists, record in the 23:00 record. This attribute is used to find likely errors in the dataset, where for streams, a 3 degree difference in water temperature between successive hours likely indicates out of water.
Water Temperature Daily Mean deg (F). Averaged water temperature for the calendar day. If hourly data exists, record in the 23:00 record.

Water Temperature Difference deg (F) b/w Successive Daily Means, The absolute (ABS) difference in deg (F) of the current day daily mean and the previous day daily mean, where current refers to any given day and previous refers the day immediately preceeding the current day, If hourly data exists, record in the 23:00 record. This attribute is used to find likely errors in the dataset, where for streams, a 3 degree difference in water temperature between successive daily means likely indicates out of water.
Water Temperature Daily Min deg (F), The daily minimum water temperature in deg (F). If hourly data exists, record in the 23:00 record.
Water Temperature Daily Max deg (F), The daily minimum water temperature in deg (F). If hourly data exists, record in the 23:00 record.

Water Temperature 7-day Average Daily Max deg (F), The water temperature average in deg (F) of the current daily max and the (6) previous daily max. If hourly data exists, record in the 23:00 record..
Comments, free form text for interesting or unusual sightings, problems, or issues.

dataTable.entityDescription: A summary table of summer water temperature in streams in deg (F) for all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2017. Includes maximums and counts for water temperature, 7 day average daily maximum, and thermistors suspected to be out of water when >= 3 degrees (F) difference occurs between Successive Hours or Successive Daily Means.
